document.title: Wise Teaching to Students’ Kinesthetic Intelligence: The Teacher as Surrogate, Guru, Foreshadower, Choreographer, or Expeditionist
document.abstract: Based on the degree of the teacher’s perceived skill, engagement, and role play with her students, this model posits six distinct styles of teaching to students’ kinesthetic intelligence and differentiates their effects on learning.
document.publication-title: The Journal of the Assembly for Expanded Perspectives on Learning

field.name: acknowledgements
field.value: Sara K. Schneider teaches qualitative methods and cross-cultural studies and co-directs the Interdisciplinary Studies Program in the National College of Education at National-Louis University in Chicago. Author of the monthly e-zine Skin in the Game (www.thinkingdr.com) as well as the books Concert Song as Seen: Kinesthetic Aspects of Musical Interpretation, Vital Mummies: Performance Design for the Show-Window Mannequin, and Art of Darkness: Ingenious Performances by Undercover Operators, Con Men, and Others, she writes and leads workshops about the body’s role in spiritual practice, learning, work, and culture.
